instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3302: What is 820-3302? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Only the first led lights when you turn on the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL>.
There was a short in <CAPACITOR>C9480</CAPACITOR>. I replaced the <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR>, but without result.

Voltage: 
- <SIGNAL>PP12V_S5</SIGNAL> 12.07V
- <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 4.97V
- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.30V
- <SIGNAL>PP12V_S0</SIGNAL> 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
LED501 doesn't lit before pressing the power button?
Do you note any pulse on other LEDs when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?
Also check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 79599, member: 682"]
LED501 doesn't lit before pressing the power button?
[/QUOTE]

Yes, it does.
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 79599, member: 682"]
Do you note any pulse on other LEDs when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?
[/QUOTE]

No pulse on LEDs when triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 79599, member: 682"]
Also check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).
[/QUOTE]

Yes, there is a pulse drop in <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
"Yes, there is a pulse drop in <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>."
Then check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PN_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, at same time.

BTW, inch style quotes ("") make the post more aesthetic than the way you've choosed...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
''Then check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, at same time."
It starts at 0V and when it triggers the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> is high at 3,3V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Then you should have <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL> present.
Change <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR>.
